title: A Classic Western
text:
Killer's Choice is a classic western tale by one of my facvorite western writers, Jack Bickham, aka Jeff Clinton. (Most of his westerns were published under the Clinton name)

The protagonist, a man with gunsmoke in his distant past, is a small but respected rancher with a wife (who abhors violent men) and a son. When a range war breaks out tht takes the life of his best friend, he is torn between his duty to his friend, his need to keep his past a secret, and his fear that his wife will reject him if he straps on a gun. And when it becomes clear to him that the killer is a professional gunman that only he has the skills to defeat, the conflict intensifies.

Add to that an element of mystery.... was the killer hired by the logical suspect, or are there more dimensions than appeat?

Clinton is a good writer and a master plotter.

If you like Westerns, this is well worth your time.

title: A Thought-Provoking Treatise on the Modern Biopharmaceutical Industry
text:
A thought-provoking treatise on the modern biopharmaceutical industry, Peter deftly navigates through the political spin and bluster that shrouds one of the most disliked and demonized sectors of our modern economy with compelling arguments for maximizing innovation while doing right by patients in The Great American Drug Deal. Weaving together numerous examples and vignettes from his incredible vantage point as a scientist, life sciences entrepreneur, and biotech investor, Peter does an outstanding job of highlighting the warped incentives of stakeholders across the healthcare continuum, the importance of fostering a vibrant biotech industry (in a manner that feels utterly prescient during the COVID-19 pandemic), while offering fair criticisms of the industry’s excesses and malevolent actors. While Peter is certainly an outspoken and passionate defender of the industry, his policy prescriptions offer compelling food for thought for all in an accessible and pellucid manner. In fact, his newest entry only adds to his already prolific thought leadership collection—Peter’s Entrepreneur’s Guide to a Biotech Startup has been a must-read for any budding biotech enthusiast with hopes of bringing to market scientific cures for nearly two decades now along with his numerous and thoughtful Op-Eds across the media landscape.  

A great gift for biotech enthusiasts new to the sector or veterans alike (I purchased this for one of my former interns)—I highly recommend this book to anyone with a semblance of interest in the industry or curious about drug pricing reform (and the unintended consequences of well-intentioned, but misguided proposals from Washington on patients and the industry alike). I also recommend that any students with an interest in the biotech sector register for Peter's The Business of Biotechnology course; the team at RA Capital have done a really great job in giving back to the biotech community with free courses and training for the next generation of life sciences leaders.

title: Not a Penance to Read this One.
text:
It is summer 1323, Sir Baldwin and Simon are about to leave on a pilgrimage. They are going to travel across Europe to Santiago de Compostela. Foreign travel is dangerous even for well armed men, and attacks on pilgrims are common place, but an even greater menace hangs over the city of Santiago.

title: Meticulously researched, engagingly presented critique.
text: Paul Begala makes the case with research, not rancor, that Senator McCain's record, rhetoric and proposals promise a continuation, not a break from, the Bush Administration's economic, social, deregulatory, military and foreign polices.  He avoids the common pitfalls of such political accounts:  this is neither the dry scorecard of a policy "insider," nor the zingy yet unsubstantiated riposte of the "pundit."  Rather, it is a mature, concise, specific accounting of Republican policies, John McCain's support for them, and their devastating effects on the nation.  It should have been "must" reading for undecided voters.

title: Fantastic adventure
text:
This book was quite entertaining, it had me hooked to the end. It’s true to Rick Riordan's fast-paced style, but is also unique from his other books. The book doesn’t have any slow points in it and it’s obvious Riordan researched his Nordic mythology.
The story’s main character, Magnus Chase, starts as a 16 year old homeless kid living on the streets of Boston. He has two good friends and some family connections he is no longer associating with anymore, but otherwise he’s alone. However, on his 16th birthday, his Uncle takes him to a river, and it changes his life forever. He ends up summoning the Sword of Summer from the river's depths, one of the most powerful weapons in Nordic mythology. He is then attacked by a fire giant, who wants the sward. Why? You have to read it to find out.
It is difficult to say much more about the story without spoiling it, but Magnus must go on a quest to save the nine worlds from burning in fire. Along the way he faces both unique physical and mental challenges. He meets new people, including humans, gods, and monsters alike. It was 400 pages of fun, and I’m excited for the next book in the series.
Personally, I grew rather attached to several of the characters and was engrossed by the daring tasks Magnus and his company had to accomplish. As usual in Rick Riordan’s books, there was a good touch of humor and fast-paced writing style that keep today's society entertained and keeps the book from ever getting too boring. It was quite the page turner, and thanks to Riordan’s clean writing, I would highly recommend it for all ages.

title: Mainly recipes from 19th century Mexican cookbooks, not an original work or particularly Californian
text:
The positive reviews this book has received on Amazon notwithstanding, I don’t like it at all. My dislike is partly due to the editor/translator, whose translations offend me – for example, he consistently translates almidón (starch) as corn flour, correct in UK English but not in unitedstatesian – and whose comments strike me as tendentious and false.

In his introductory comments, he wrote on p. 22:

She managed to express her disdain for the Anglos by mocking their recipes, such as ham and eggs, with a satirical title: huevos hipocrítas.

The recipe isn’t Pinedo’s and was first published well before unitedstatesians began moving to California. She lifted it nearly word-for-word from p. 167 of El Cocinero Mexicano (1831), Tomo I, or p. 418 of Diccionario de Cocina o El Nuevo Cocinero Mexicano (1845). Both books were published in México by a Mexican for a Mexican audience. Their huevos hipocrítas isn’t a typical anglo dish:

After cutting ham in thin slices, fry them in butter. When they’re done, arrange on a plate and pour the butter in which they were fried on them. Break the eggs and put them on top of the ham, sprinkle with fine salt, pepper and grated nutmeg. Cook at medium heat until they set. (my translation)

I don’t believe that unitedstatesians prepare ham and eggs this way. We typically fry ham and eggs separately and serve them side by side. We don’t cook eggs on top of ham or season fried eggs with nutmeg.

I have the original. On p. vi Pinedo remarks negatively about English cooks.

“There’s not a single good English cook and their dishes and way of seasoning them is the most insipid and flavorless that can be hoped for.” (my translation)

This is a typical comment on nineteenth century English cooking. I found no reference in the book to the United States or to US cooking.

About Pinedo’s recipes. Many were lifted, often mangled in the process, from older Mexican cookbooks published in México. Her principal sources seem to have been Diccionario de Cocina o El Nuevo Cocinero Mexicano (1845) and Novisimo arte de cocina (1831), both with many later editions.

M. E. Johnson’s Bellota y Calabasas en el Tapanco, comidas sabrosa en la casa, published in Los Angeles in 1895, gives what is probably a more accurate view of Californian cuisine at the end of the nineteenth century.

title: Best of Ancient Mythology
text:
This is one of the greatest mythological tales recorded. Unlike what the summary says, it is not the 'closest thing Ireland has to a national epic'. The Irish national epic would be the Leabhar Gabhala, the Book of Invasions, or possible the Fenian Cycle. It is the certainly the great epic of Ulster, however, and I don't mean to reduce it at all.
The literary wealth, the humor, violent single combat, and glimpse into Gaelic culture makes this a must-read for anyone who wants to understand the ancient (and modern) Irish.
Beir bua!

title: Twisty
text:
Dear Wife was a slow buildup for me. It bounced from 3 perspectives: Beth, Jeffrey and Marcus. Throughout the book, it is unknown exactly who Beth is. From the first page, you learn that Beth is on the run from her husband. Then you learn that Jeffrey’s wife, Sabine, is missing. Marcus is the detective assigned to the case. The story is so well written that it took me about 80% of the book to figure out what was what. And even then, there were still elements that surprised me. The story just keeps getting more intricate, more layers added as it goes on.
Once I finished, I had to sit and think back over it because I wasn’t sure exactly how I felt about it. It has such a realistic feel to it. Likely because this type of scenario happens more than anyone wants to think about. Another factor could be that the book is based in Arkansas and Georgia- the Arkansas city being only 45 minutes away from where I was born. (It’s so rare to find my state mentioned in books).
It’s so hard to write this review and not give anything away! So many things I want to discuss but that’s best left for a book club.
I want to thank Kimberly Belle, Harlequin Trade Publishing and Netgalley for the opportunity to read this book in exchange for an unbiased opinion. All thoughts are my own.

title: This edition is excellent, the new one with the yellow square on the cover is disappointing
text:
This guides are excellent for planning your trip ahead in terms of what places suit your interests better, not really for looking up lodging and meals (Same applies to Insight Guides - Discovery). We use both guides to plan our trip, since National Geographic seems to have a bit better pictures and Insight Guides a more enthusiastic writing team, so National Geographic encourages you visually, while Insight Guides encourages you with their writing about the places, people and traditions. NG is very recommended for people enjoying hiking or visiting beautiful scenery places, since they give also very good advise on this. Once you know what you would like to visit, you can use the internet, your travel agent or local Information centers for lodging...

Pros:
+ the photographs and the quality of the paper is much better than in most guides, so it's a pleasure to pick the spots you would like to visit. (Con: since the paper is much better, the guide is heavy for its size, so no too good to carry in your bag)
+ Has a lot of outdoor & countryside places to choose from, not just cities and museums. Flora and fauna information & pictures are also included (Con: for most of the recommended places you need a car to get to them, since often they are not near regular public transport routes)
+ Has nice 1 day or half day walking tours inside cities or car routes from one point to the next, highlighting the special interest sites and indicating aprox. times for completing them.

Cons (Please note that despite the Cons, if we could only buy one guide, we would buy NG):
- Reading somewhat dry and very factual, not really enthusiastical (Insight Guides - Discovery seem better in this respect). This does not mean NG lacks information, it's just they do not use too many adjectives like "superb", "fantastic", "terrific", etc.
- Not too much information about people and their traditions (Insight Guides - Discovery has a bit more on these topics)
- The binding is not so good, in 2 of our guides, pages went loose, so we are now very careful in the handling, not to "open" the guide completely,(Insight Guides - Discovery are better in this respect).

title: GECKO makes the Komodo Dragon look like a poodle.
text:
Horror, just the way I like it. This was the first of Jack Priest's books I have read and I was not disappointed. I won't go into a narrative of what the book is about, as several others have already done that much better than I. But let me say the creature of the title is a frightening, relentless monster that leaves a very bloody, and uncompromising trail of bodies as it is unleashed upon the unsuspecting characters, who find themselves in a maelstrom of intense terror.

There is one particular element to this book which struck me as one of the most original ideas I have ever seen (or read). I won't spoil it for you except to say it concerns the "connection" between the main character Jim Monday and Donna.

Jack Priest is a fresh and imaginative voice in the world of horror literature and I will be reading his books for many years to come. I hope you will too.

title: 4.5 Stars Review!
text:
The Most Expensive Night of Her Life by Amy Andrews: Blake Walker knows how to do a lot of things. He's great at keeping a schedule, he's a perfectionist when it comes to woodworking, and he has a bit of experience with flying bullets. Ava Kelly, supermodel and diva wasn't something he'd planned to deal with when his renovation job was over. Blake admitted, he couldn't keep his eyes off her, and she seemed to love the work he and his crew had done to her house. But with a month-long vacation coming the day after this job was done, he'd be glad to see the back of her.

Ava wasn't used to people who weren't intimidated by her. Not that she liked that kind of attention, but there was just something about Blake - her very handsome contractor - that made her want to bait him at every turn. She could see that her over the top complaints got to him, but he just wouldn't let his irritation show. It was infuriating. Especially when she not only admired his handiwork, but the delicious package he came in.

Neither of them expected his hidden talent to come in handy on the last day of the job. Ava is just about to bid goodbye to Blake when shots fire and he tackles her to keep her safe. Totally swoon-worthy. Okay, the swooning may have been partly due to the knot on her skull when she hit the pavement, but that's not important. What is however, is taking some time off under the radar so the police can find out who's after her. Her agent wants to book her in to her regular hotel, but something tells her she'll be safe with Blake - just for one night.

Blake is shocked when she asks him to meet her at the hospital. After all, she's not hurt too badly - and his servitude to her is at an end. He can't help it if she's got some weirdo trying to gun her down. He did what he always does. Reacted like a soldier. He didn't go above and beyond - he just helped another person when the chips were down. When she asks to stay with him for a night until she can figure out what to do, his answer is clear. A firm NO. But she knows his weakness. His sister runs a charity for wounded soldiers that needs an infusion of cash to continue operating, and she's willing to donate it. Blake can't be selfish and say no to help for his sister - after failing her when she needed him most.

When 'one night' turns into 'take me along on your boating vacation' - Blake's had enough. There's no way he can stay cooped up in his one-bedroom houseboat for a week or more. But Ava manages to pull another trump card. Not only will she donate the million pounds, she'll become her sister's high-profile benefactor. Against every one of his better judgments, he feels like he has to say yes.

Both Blake and Ava have issues with trust, but can they trust each other enough to give in to their attraction and keep it casual? I guessed no, and I was right. :-)

I loved this book. Really, truly, loved it. That's saying something, because after reading the first few pages, I was ready to hate Ava. Swanning about her property making demands of the 'servants' (that's never said btw, just the feeling I got). But when the perspective changes from Blake to Ava - her attitude is explained immediately.

Both of the main characters have perception issues - some dealing with their bodies, and some dealing with how other people see them through their actions. Ava was more comfortable with her problems, but she'd been dealing with them her entire life. Blake's were more recent, and much more serious. I was touched by how Ava reacted to each new thing she learned about Blake - and I'm ashamed to say I might not have handled things as tactfully as she did.

Amazing story, great characters, really intense situations, and super hot love scenes. Give Ava a few pages and I think you'll like her. Blake... I have no allusions - you'll want him to be your boyfriend.

title: If you like popular science books, then this one might not be for you...sorry!
text: Non-scientists who have read a lot of popular books on physics might find Dr. Muller’s latest work confusing.  Perhaps one good example is this quote from "Now": “we know from relativity that since waves carry energy, they also carry mass, and gravity does indeed pull on them.”  More carefully written books will point out that the mass component of E=mc² goes to zero for electromagnetic waves and that the other part of the equation involving momentum dominates.  But, that’s not even discussed until much later and then not very well, leaving the reader to ponder: if light has mass, wouldn’t it be infinite?  There seems to be a lot of this sort of sloppiness in the book spread amongst some insightful gems in the first half, but, particularly towards the end, he asserts with authority things which just should not be asserted as true in a popular science book which explains a new theory, one of them being: “I do know I have a soul.”  You’ll see that bit of strangeness scattered here and there in the book and perhaps wonder what these assertions have to do with the subject of defining “Now” and presenting his new theory of time.  Overall, “Now” might not be the best book for non-physicists unless you are prepared to do some very deep research (e.g., if there is no future, as Dr. Muller claims, then how do present particles in the lab entangle with future particles? ).  Dr. Muller even challenges theories of Dr. Stephen Hawking, which a few non-scientists might find somewhat supercilious.

title: A Nice Companion
text:
I've loved the Hanson-Roberts deck for so long. I got mine twenty-two years ago, and it's still one of my favorites. So, when I saw the book to accompany it I felt I should have it. I didn't really need it, since any book that uses a RWS type deck could be used to work with the Hanson-Roberts deck, it was more about finally having a book to specifically go with that deck. I mostly loved what I was able to learn after all these years about Mary Hanson-Roberts herself, in the bio on her! I do have to say I think they really cut corners with the book in making the pictures of the cards in the book in black & white. It feels like a casual xeroxed copy or something. I guess that was my biggest disappointment. I enjoyed author Susan Hansson's writing and descriptions of the cards, and I wish she'd had more editorial freedom to expand more of the material squeezed in at the end on using Tarot for meditation, and the various spreads and readings.

I do enjoy the handy compact size though, and overall am glad to have this book at last.

title: Compelling!  (A bit too compelling, in fact.)
text: A (rather too) fast-moving and enthralling narrative, as the horse transports man through a flawless dressage by millennial leaps and bounds of history.  The text is in fact as forceful (by dint of its outstanding dearth of equivocation) as an 8,000-horsepower locomotive, which cannot be derailed, or even sidetracked by the cautionary semaphores of circumspect modern historians.  The author took the bit between her teeth (so to speak) and began with a nuclear thesis that the horse successively revolutionized human transport and then warfare, and was the vehicle that took Indo-European languages and culture from an Urheimat at the western borders of the Eurasian steppe to its farther adventitious and evolutionary manifestations in the four directions of the compass, reviving the centum-satem dichotomy in the process.  The most-critical previous review rightly calls attention to the author's facile (and mostly tacit) ironing-out of wrinkles and patching-over of holes in the very thin and worn fabric of ancient history and prehistory in this largely unobstructed narrative; and the reviewer is correct in observing that selected parenthetical literature citations do not substitute for substantive argumentation. Kelekna essentially has cherry-picked published opinions, however distant from the scholarly center of gravity they might be, and deployed them as if they were proofs of what she wrote -- which they are not; I would be surprised, in fact, if the very authors she cites would not disagree with a variety of points in Kelekna's rather implausibly tight-knit synthesis.  Nevertheless, her fundamental tenets relating to the consequences of horse domestication and use of the horse in transport and warfare are cogently argued, and the ritual significance of the horse in various apparently related ancient cosmologies and religions seems incontrovertible.  So, taking the mean of 2 stars for liberties freely taken with historicity and 4 stars for stimulation and interest, I award 3 stars.  If the axe had not been ground quite so feverishly and myopically, this might have been a very nice piece of scholarship -- but then, of course, we would have something much more voluminous, and less certain, with numerous tangents, and consequently soporific for the general reader.  People, it seems, demand to know the "bottom line", even where none can be drawn by informed consensus.  Here you can find it (a bottom line, not a consensus).

title: It's a Letter to U.S. Citizens We Need to Hear
text:
Does it ramble in some places? Yes. Does it propose some things that kinda scare me? Yes. Does it come up with brilliant, new and wholly-thought-out ways to change the world? No. Now, let's ask ourselves what it was meant to do...

It was meant to walk a reader through the mental steps it takes to lift themselves out of seeing their entire lives in the context of only their own navels. It's not intended to show people exactly how to change the world. It's intended to show people how to think about themselves as agents of change...and changes that could happen TODAY. Sadly, that type of cover description doesn't sell books. So, I'm sure there will be people complaining about how it doesn't deliver on its promises. Well, welcome to the world of book-selling. Now, get over it.

Get over it and read this book. It's been a huge factor in my being able to finally see where I fit in as a citizen of this world...not just a participant in my life. Read it. Let it scare you and then pull back. Let it make you say, "DUH!" and then surprise you by the next sentence's depth and insight. If it were a man, I'd recommend you kiss him just so you can know what it's like. Yeah, it's that good. If you let it in.

title: This is NOT a book for most of us...
text:
While the cover of this book suggests it is simply about "revealing the heart of the (Milky Way) galaxy", including our galaxy's purported black hole, I found the emphasis to be quite different. From my point of view, this is a rather technical book that attempts to cover the history of astrophysics, going back to the 1600's (when scientists thought that our Milky Way galaxy comprised the entire "universe").

I have a solid background in science, going back to my time as an undergraduate, and extending to my graduate school experiences and my master's degree. However, as educated as I am in math and science (including calculus), I found much of this book to be beyond the average (educated) reader's comprehension.

It is certainly a fascinating history of astrophysics, but it is not an "easy to read" account, as one of the reviewers on the back cover suggests. Or I should say that it's not an "easy to comprehend" book..

Also, the drawings and photos are all in low resolution black & white, which in no way adequately conveys the excitement and beauty of our (or any other) galaxy. If you are really interested in astronomy and the beauty of the universe, I highly recommend that you bookmark NASA's "Astronomy Picture of the Day" website, available for free at the website 'apod.nasa.gov'.

Each of the daily archived photos is fascinating, colorful, high-resolution, and each has a wonderful description of the day's astronomical event. Just remember to click on "ARCHIVE" at the bottom of the website's main page.

title: Rather tedious
text: The concept sounded quite interesting but the novel was so caught up in the characters thoughts which they repeatedly tortured themselves, as well as me, with that I became exasperated early on. Unfortunate circumstances drove them apart for 10 years, both blamed the other, thought each other was a criminal, had abandoned them, yet as soon as they re met they had passionate sex and then spent chapters justifying their negative beliefs, kept having sex, etc. The story occasionally briefly picked up and everything was hunky-dory for a bit. I think it's amusing how some readers become so involved with the characters, as if they were real people, and write long descriptions of why they hate, or dislike them, as if it weren't fiction. I see from some other reviews that many readers were disappointed.

title: Ten Thumbs UP!
text:
This book was published in 1968. This is a great reference source if you want one for this famous WWII fighter group. It is more affordable than the most detailed publication "Jonah's Feet Are Dry" and for me that was important.

It has a fair number of pictures of the group's aircraft, but you can find more of those online. What I liked the most were the detailed accounts of the missions involving aerial combat, as well as detailed explanations of losses and the pilots who scored on those missions. It begins to put the 353rd's history in place for the reader.

The 4th fighter group gets the most press, but you get tired of hearing the same old story told fifty different ways. You can meet the 353rd's pilots. They were a great bunch of aviators and deserve attention just as much as the 4th's men. Welcome to another 8th Air Force fighter group-the Slybirds!

title: fast-paced, full of depth, personality, and even some humor
text:
As the fifth book in Elly Griffiths' series about forensic archeologist Ruth Galloway, _A Dying Fall_ differs in some ways from the previous four books. This one takes place largely in the north of England, and for various reasons, the main characters all end up being there at the same time--Ruth and her daughter Kate, Cathbad, DCI Nelson, and his wife Michelle. As has been the case in the earlier books, Griffiths' description is highly atmospheric; one is immediately immersed in a setting that is vivid and unique. This one was perhaps a little less complicated in its plot than some of the others in the series, but it still offers great pleasure, and it also means that it's less important to have read the previous books in the series. There is still a bit of humor in the writing too, which is very enjoyable.

There are of course some stylistic similarities in Griffiths' mysteries too, such as the writing in present tense. This feature has bothered some readers, but I feel that it conveys a feeling of experiencing events as they happen. The story is narrated too, so that the reader knows more than any of the characters, and that too is quite special. There is plenty of suspense, as well as a chilling scene in the latter part of the book, both of which add significantly to the pacing and keep one's interest nicely. The young Kate is a real charmer, and Cathbad is less shadowy and mysterious than he has been in previous books. Like some other reviewers, I would say this book is the best of the series so far, but it's a tough choice. They're all first-rate mysteries, and I'm eagerly looking forward to the next one.

title: Disjointed...
text:
Based on all the rave reviews that this book received, I should have loved it. Instead, I had to force myself to complete this pretentious, plodding bore, since I truly hate to give up on any book

I found the characters to not be at all well defined. Just when I though I might get some deeper insight into one of them, the author moved on to another character. The book starts out with e-mails from Jerome to Howard. Very interesting. However, Jerome essentially disappears from the rest of the book. Claire, Carl, and Levi - I was waiting to find out a great deal more about these characters, but instead I had to read the boring and incredibly predictable scene in which Victoria and Howard have sex (honestly, who was surprised by this?) What is the hot, sexy college student Victoria's motivation for wanting to have sex with the 50ish year old Howard? This is never explained. And in the end, when Howard spurns her further advancements, do we find out anything more about her? No. We do however find out that Howard simply likes her. Why? What's to like?

I also found the story to be incredibly disjointed. Various story lines were started and then dropped. Howard's visit with his father, the developing friendship between Kiki and Carlene, The painting that Carlene "willed" to Kiki, Jerome's Christianity and many others. None of these things were explored to their fullest.

The author must have been paid by the word. There are numerous page long plus paragraphs that say absolutely nothing. This book needed a better editor since it could have been shortened by about 100 pages and we wouldn't have missed a thing.

Another reviewer recommended Richard Russo's STRAIGHT MAN and I couldn't agree more. It is a wonderful book about academia. Better characters, better story. Give that one a try instead.

title: Another Riveting Ride!
text:
Grace Simms is a beautiful psychotherapist. Conscientious to a fault, she always wants to help her patients, no matter what, no matter how she’s feeling herself. We definitely see these patients up close in their intense, truthful, and insightful therapy sessions: an unfaithful husband, a couple with an abusive husband, an inappropriate flirt, a man entering a complicated relationship, and a disturbed woman who keeps talking to her “angel.”

But Grace has her own issues. She’s been a friend to and romantically interested in a married man for years, who has just now returned––still married. Then, after she notices a distant person as a stalking presence, a button is stolen from her favorite office chair, and a blank note is shoved under her door, tensions heat up. She contacts a very attractive detective from years before who comes to help and protect her, yet ends up adding more complication in her life. For, as their mutual attraction grows, it all adds to her already swirling mind.

Then, when someone nearby is murdered, the overall fear ratchets up exponentially. No longer is each patient possibly a stalker; now he/she could be a murderer. For me, throughout, those pages couldn’t turn fast enough. And how about that ending! What is it, you may ask? You’ll just have to read the book to find out. All I can say is, having been exposed to this author’s work before, I knew I would be in for an intriguing ride, and indeed, I was. Highly recommend!

title: Enjoyed the audiobook version
text:
I liked this book more than I thought I would. I listened to the audiobook version read by the author. I feel like I connected more to what the author was trying to convey while listening. I especially enjoyed the chapter where she talks about her relationship with her mom.

I have been reading this author's blog for many years, and there was one thing that I felt like she glossed over in her book. The author speaks of a relationship with a man where she was shamed for the amount of food she was eating. She touches on her inability to speak up and talk about why she needed to eat what she was eating and when (she was training for a marathon). She states that she hadn't thought about what she was eating in over 20 years and that the actions of the person she was in a relationship with at the time put her back in a place where she experienced negative thoughts about her body and eating habits. As a reader of her blog for many years, I have noticed that one of the main themes of this author's writing is what she is eating/not eating and what exercise regimen she is following FAITHFULLY. She is ALWAYS doing SOMETHING. Valedictorian style. She's not eating sugar, she's doing a juice fast, she's doing Paleo, she's eating "clean", she's vegan. She's doing spin classes, she's running marathons, she's running stairs, she's lifting weights...and ALL of these eating habits/exercise regimens have CHANGED HER LIFE. Her body image issues are discussed somewhat in the book, but to say that she only had one episode of disordered thinking/eating in 20 years is a gross understatement.

Overall am glad that I listened to this book. I am happy that the treatment helped the author come out of her deep depression and that she is able to share hope with others. I hope she finds peace and is able to continue to heal.

title: Terror in the Big Apple
text:
As am member of NYPD’s Intelligence unit, Jeremy Fisk has no shortage of enemies among the terrorist element. This fact hits close to home when he is attacked at home by three men. Upon further investigation, it is discovered that his address had been made public after a man named Verlyn Merritt releases sensitive NYPD documents to Wikileaks. Merritt is taken into custody but cleared of involvement in the attack on Fisk. Shortly there after, a series of random shootings start to occur. The shooter issues an ultimatum: one citizen will be shot each day until Merritt is released. The atmosphere of the city becomes one of terror, as citizens are too scared to leave their homes. As the death count rises, time is running out for the NYPD to discover who is behind these attacks and how to stop them.

The Ultimatum by Dick Wolf, is the third entry in the new series by the well-known creator of Law and Order. At the center of the series is veteran NYPD Intelligence detective Jeremy Fisk. Just like his notable TV series, The Ultimatum draws its inspiration from real-life events and the result is a captivating novel that seems all too possible. The depth of the characters and pace of the story demonstrate Wolf’s skill as a writer. The plot does not get bogged down in technical details but has enough to keep the reader motivated to read further. I look forward to the continuation of this series and give this book 4/5 stars.

*This book was the only compensation received for this review.*

title: Not the real Merrick, but an enjoyable fictional biography
text: I believe this is one of the first books I've read that is based on the movie, rather than vice versa. At times it crosses the line into sentimentality, but romantics will take heart and a handful of tissues. Both the movie and the book condensed and misrepresented the real history of the real Elephant Man for dramatic effect. They also got his name wrong; it was Joseph and not John, but this is a common mistake attributed to his doctor's memoir. However, what Christine Sparks captures is the humanity of a man who was barely accepted as human, who in turn inspired others to view their own lives and the things we easily take for granted through his eyes. The earnestness of Merrick and his pure joy at the simple pleasures in life, like hearing the happy laughter of the nurses on the ward, remind the reader of how easy it to be distracted from enjoying life.

The reader may not need or be attracted to each project (with 30 in all, she offers a BIG range to choose from!), but there is a great deal of information to be gleaned from each one. This would be a great gift, for yourself or for any woodworker-crafter.

title: I wish I could be ordinary genius
text:
One potential problem with group biographies, even with a group of two individuals, is that the members of the group may not have much to do with eachother. In this case, Max Delbruck and George Gamow were acquaintances and then friends from their 20s, so this problem does not arise. Delbruck, of German origin, and Gamow, of Russian origin, were both physicists who shifted their studies from pure physics to what we would call molecular biology for Delbruck and mostly astrophysics and cosmology for Gamow. Delbruck was born in Berlin in 1906 (he died in 1980) and Gaow in Odessa in 1904 (he died in 1968) When they started their careers as physicists, they were both focused on quantum mechanics, the hot topic in physics in the 1920s. They met at the German university at Gottingen in 1928, and lat Institute for Theoretical Physics run by the Danish physicist Niels Bohr. Delbruck seems to have had difficulty in finding a niche in physics and while working as a phyicist at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Berlin in the 1930s became interested in molecular biology. He moved to the United States in the late 1930s and realized while at the California Institute of Technology that bateriophages, viruses that infect bacteria, would be a good model system for determining what the physical nature of the gene was. Starting in the 1940s Delbruck ran an influential short course on the uses of bacteriophages in genetic research at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory on Long Island. Delbruck's work with Salvador Luria using bacteriophages was influential in genetics research. Gamov escaped from the Soviet Union in the early 1930s and took a position at George Washington University in Washington D. C. He organized a series of influential conferences which got him interested in the physics of stars and cosmology. With his collaborators Ralph Alpher and Robert Herman, Gamov developed an early version of the Big Bang model of the origin of the universe in the 1940s. Unfortunately, this work did not have the impact one might have hoped, and in particular no empirical work was done on the subject for about 15 years, by which time their papers appear to have been forgetten. Gamow also wrote a number of well-recieved popular science books.

I first posted this review at goodreads.com

On the other hand, I did enjoy those details that did get into the stories, though. They included stories from people from Africa, Pakistan, India, Kosovo, the Philippines, Europe, to name a few.

This was the cleverest project, that to me is of great importance. We need to as a people, be respectful and thoughtful of cultures other than our own, and respect their perspective and experience. I feel like everyone should read this book. The chapters are small, the stories are not forced. It would do anyone good to read it.

title: A new appalachian literature classic! I smell a CRC series!!!
text: As a child, I imagined being a young girl lost inside the Biltmore home during its prime. Robert Beatty has surpassed my hope of bringing that dreamy idea to fruition. Serafina's story will capture hearts (in a good way, unlike the Black Cloak) and fascinate both young and old readers. While I could have read this story cover to cover in just one day, my kids wouldn't allow me the freedom to do so. For those who don't know Biltmore, the story paints the beautiful home and some of its history quite well. For those who have visited Biltmore (even multiple times, like myself), the story brings more magic to the readers' memories of their own experiences at the estate. As a teacher, I can envision a whole literature unit based on the book, a study of the history and geography of the region, and of course class field trips. I would recommend and describe it to mature elementary students and adults as a heroine-based, Harry Potter-type story set in early America. I look forward to sharing "Serafina and the Black Cloak" with my young daughters as soon as they're ready to listen to a chapter book and taking them to visit the estate someday. Well done, Mr. Beatty! I hope to read more about Serafina in the future!

title: Delicious silliness for grownup children
text:
Blue Diamond Delivery, Anne Johnson, publication date June 25, 2013

I didn't realize until I was quite a few pages into the book that this was a sequel to a previous book. Blue Diamond Delivery is a sequel to Green Light Delivery. It offers another look into the worlds of the more-than-a-little strange citizens in the Raralt Planetary Circle. In particular, it's about Webrid, Stravin and Zatell -- three friends and three separate species, two of whom are scientists -- one with feathers, another with many arms and/or legs. The third -- our hero -- is a big furry dude. A carter.

There's a supporting cast of weirdos, all of whom who spend lots of time drinking themselves into a stupor while contemplating sex with oddly configured other species.

The basic plot? Webrid -- a Yeril -- is a carter. He delivers stuff throughout the planetary system. Or used to, before (in the previous book I didn't read) he saved the world. That was when he got very rich and didn't have to cart anymore.

Webrid doesn't live like a rich guy. He lives like a drunken slob because that's what he is. And that's exactly what he wants to be. He just happens to be a multi-millionaire drunken slob.

When his world is rocked by massive earthquakes that destroy his home and threaten to wipe out his city, planet and the entire Raralt Circle of planets, he isn't surprised the government calls on him to deliver a gigantic blue diamond to the machine that holds the planets in orbit. This is no ordinary delivery. The fate of every living creature on all the planets in the Circle depends on it and Webrid. Or, more to the point, Webrid and his pals.

Webrid owns the cart and has the brawn and determination to get the job done. He pals Stravin and Zatell have the brains to figure out how. Zatell also has a rocket ship, an important component. And Stravin has a few other critical items they're going to need to pull off this "saving the world" thing.

Webrid is not quite a hero, even a reluctant one. He's a good carter. If he has a delivery to make, he will make it or die trying, though he is not averse to some hot babes and a sea of booze too. He figures the booze and hot babes are the point. Yerils are big and strong, but the species is firmly committed to cowardice and self-interest. Odd how Webrid keeps saving the day, even though he doesn't know what or why he's doing what he's doing. Usually.

It took me a while to realize how funny this book is. Talk about over-thinking a story, I was trying to figure out what these characters might actually look like until I realized it didn't matter. My job was to read and enjoy it. After that, I enjoyed it very much.

I'm glad I stuck with the book. It got funnier and funnier as it went along until I found myself laughing out loud at the delicious silliness of the characters and story.

I highly recommend the book if you (a) have a taste for bizarre science fiction and (b) don't mind species with incomprehensible body designs. If you just roll with it, you'll enjoy clever dialogue, weird inventions and outlandish technology. Blue Diamond Delivery could be a great animated feature film. It's pure fun and reminds me of some of the books I read to my son when he was young, but aimed at adults. Childish adults. Like me.

Enjoy. You can get it in paperback and I'm guessing on Kindle too since the review copy is Kindle format. You can order the paperback from Amazon.com and probably elsewhere too.

title: A venerable successor to the original Encyclopedia of Chess Middlegames
text: With its predecessor currently out-of-print, now appears the successor to the original Encyclopedia of Chess Middlegame Combinations from Sahovski Informator (Chess Informant). Every bit as comprehensive as its big brother, this excellent book again takes the most intriguing middlegame positions from world-class games and delivers them as problems divided into the most typical tactical categories. Additionally, this volume is also available on disk for those who prefer their data delivered digitally. The biggest difference... thanks to modern digital chess fonts, all the diagrams are completely crisp, clear, and free of all the flaws that characterize "hot lead" typesetting from "ye olde daze." Imagine each square acid-etched into a little block of metal, fitted with its 63 cousins into a square jig. Ink would clog up the little lines used to symbolize dark squares. And if the little metal block represented a black piece on a dark square, it would sometimes muddy up all the way into a black blotch. Hooray for the modern computer chess fonts.

title: The First Non-Sports Book I Loved
text:
A few years ago, for reasons I couldn't remember if my life depended on it, I bought a book that didn't have to do with sports. It was Tom Clancy's Red Storm Rising. At the time I didn't have any knowledge whatsoever of military happenings in the world. I remembered the Gulf War as a nuissance that the news had aired for a month instead of sports (gasp!). Until RSR, I hadn't read a book that was longer than 300 pages. Sound familiar? I'm writing this review for those of you who are like I was.
The first time I read Red Storm Rising, it took me about a week. I don't remember why (I have a terrible memory, don't I?), but I loved it, even though I didn't understand most of the jargon and tactics. I then embarked on a week of net-surfing to learn everything I could about the weapon systems Clancy described. I even borrowed a book from the library about the Cold War, and this is at age fifteen (my friends thought I was nuts). Then I read my new favorite book again, and I actually understood a lot of the air, land, and sea combat sequences.
Anyway, one book doesn't make an addiction, so the next trip to the bookstore I bought "The Hunt for Red October". Take a look at its reviews and guess how I reacted to it. I was officially hooked on techno-thrillers.
Today, I have every book in the Tom Clancy collection (except for the Net Forces and Powerplays), and I loved every one to one degree or another. I also have all or nearly all of Larry Bond's (who was a co-writer with Clancy on Red Storm Rising) and Stephen Coonts' books. These writers, along with Clancy, do their homework when writing their books. I haven't detected a single error in their military jargonizing (I may be wrong), and they spend a lot of time (couple hundred pages) developing the story, instead of just saying, "stuff happened, now let's get to the action!". There are also a bunch of new authors who have this skill (ie. - Patrick Robinson, James Cobb) who you should check out if you like Clancy, Coonts and Bond.
P.S. - If you really liked Red Storm Rising and you want more Cold War era NATO-USSR war books, be forewarned; there aren't many good ones. If you see one called "WWIII" by Ian Slater, don't touch it with a ten foot pole. It's a series of books, and he evidently has no knowledge at all about military hardware and international politics. Check out his reviews (I've never seen so many 1 stars).

Joe agrees to an interview that will make or break her career, but only if she agrees to join him at his large, rambunctious family's campground vacation. He ropes her into agreeing, and it is so much fun, and just the right amount of drama, to see them get to know one another again amidst the chaos of the lives of his brothers,  their wives and kids, and Keri's former best friend, his sister Terri. Concurrent stories of each of the brothers trying to salvage their own broken and challenging marriages works well, as Joe and Keri try to decide if they can heal past hurt.  Joe's family fear she will break him again and the family figures very heavily in the story. All of the action takes place on this family vacation, amidst ATVing, swimming, messy ice cream and pizza parties...lovely.  It unfolds nicely, and is  really  enjoyable to read.

I liked the other format, but the one they used did the job of explaining a summative assessment blueprint They used the revised Bloom's Taxonomy for their example which to me is very good.  I found Dr. Sivo's recommendation to be right on the mark for the topic.  For those who also are looking for a specific topic, the index is wonderfully detailed. title: Lake Charles Country Club Book Club Review
text: We found this book to be an eye-opener for us; our perception of Cleopatra has been formed from movies and legend. This historical perspective, albeit confusing at times due to the familial references, highlights her strength, cunning and vision. A visionary, her legacy of maintaining the cultural strength of Egypt supercedes her lust for self-preservation. title: "Weren't all of us bridges for each other, one way or another?"
text:
I've been a fan of Emma Donoghue's writing from the moment I first encountered her novel Room. I breezed through that book in a day, and I've eagerly awaited each of her works since. The thing I love most about opening a Donoghue novel is that I never quite know what to expect. She seems to be one of the few authors writing today who has no problem bouncing from genre to genre. No matter where her imagination takes her, Donoghue always satisfies with deeply drawn characters, elegant prose, and a keen sense of reality that makes each book a wonder to behold. Based purely upon my enjoyment of her previous works, I happily accepted a copy of her latest novel Akin to review on behalf of her publisher.

As he approaches his eightieth birthday, Noah Selvaggio has much to be proud of. Both Noah and his late wife were acclaimed chemists and professors for years. He still resides in the couples West Side apartment in New York. Though the couple never started a family of their own, they took pride in their work and the young minds they were able to influence. In preparation for his milestone birthday, Noah has decided to take a trip to the place of his birth Nice, France. He hasn't visited the city since he fled the war at the young age of four. Armed with a collection of photos that belonged to his mother, he hopes to revisit the town of his youth and piece together the puzzle that is his family history.

Just when it seems like Noah's quest to rediscover his family's past is all set, a situation with his current family intervenes. With the passing of his sister, there is no one to look after Noah's great-nephew Michael. Michael's mother is currently incarcerated, and it looks like the only thing standing between Michael and foster care is Noah. But surely Noah can't be responsible for a child. Overcome with a sense of familial duty, Noah agrees to take temporary guardianship of the boy. The odd couple of eleven-year-old and soon to be octogenarian must find common ground as they embark on a globetrotting trip to reconnect with their shared roots.

With Akin, Donoghue finds magic in the small moments between adult and child. She perfectly captures the voices of the two drastically different generations and finds humor, emotion, and understanding through the juxtaposition of the two. I was instantly taken by the internal thoughts of Noah. For a man who has prided himself on being one of the most knowledgable people in the room, his struggle to understand the mind of a child is a unique and unfamiliar challenge. Donoghue sprinkles in some mystery surrounding the photos left to Noah by his mother that adds an extra layer of depth to the family history and gives the book just enough momentum to move it beyond just the relationship between the two characters. Superbly written and emotionally satisfying, Akin is another indisputable win from Donoghue.

title: Not enough Gabriel, too much political commentary
text:
I have read all of Silva's Gabriel Allon books and enjoyed most of them...mainly because of the way Gabriel is written. He's such a painfully tragic figure. Despite his talents as a painter, despite having a loving wife and children, he's deeply haunted. Not only is he burdened by his past, but he seems almost obsessed with the need to kill in the name of the State of Israel.

The problem with "The Black Widow" is that Gabriel doesn't kick into action until 7/8th of the way through the book. The rest of the time, he's stuck in a room monitoring his field agents as they fight ISIS terrorists.

Not to get too much into politics, but Silva brings out a political sledgehammer in this one. He clearly blames Obama for pulling troops out of Iraq in 2011 and allowing ISIS to emerge. This despite the fact that Bush signed the original agreement to withdraw all troops back in 2008. Obama tried to renegotiate with Iraq to leave a residual force, but the Iraqis did not want us there. They refused to grant US troops immunity from criminal prosecution, so we pulled out as agreed.

At the time, 75% of Americans supported full withdrawal of US forces.

So it's hard to tell what Silva is driving at. Should the US have left troops in a country that did not want them? Should US troops have remained to be killed by IEDs, snipers and car bombs? Should the US now make up for it by sending ground troops into a sovereign nation (Syria) to fight ISIS? Silva certainly seems to be in favor of it.

Gabriel Allon is a wonderful character of fiction. Daniel Silva should give us more of him and less of his own armchair diplomacy.

title: Worth the read, too much happening at the end.
text:
I love these kinds of novels. I’m always up for a plot filled with intrigue, who’s going to backstab who, who’s got the dirty secrets and who’s the horrible but cunning bastage that will expose these secrets and so on….

I had to whip out my dictionary for these latin/Catholic terms that are prevalent throughout this novel. (My knowledge in Catholicism is very rusty.) But you learn something new all the time right? Now I know there’s actually names for each piece of their clothing these men wear.

I love how it in the first third of the novel the plotting to be the next pope starts. It’s a reminder that even though these people are spiritual figureheads and we look to them as authority figures, they’re still humans with ambition. But this is the part I loved reading the most. I love the intrigue, I love the plotting. I love how Lomeli is in the middle of this and is trying to make sure everything in the voting process is legitimate.

You have a group of characters to keep track of, but there isn’t much to them. They’re broken into cliques to keep track of them easily but the book is centralized on Lomeli and he’s the only one that develops throughout the novel. He’s likable for the most part and does deal with his inner self for the most part. He has his faults as well which makes sense (who doesn’t want to be pope?!) which makes these characters realistic.

The plot itself starts off really well. I liked the pace and events during the story. What bothered me was the last third of the novel where everything went chaotic and the author seemed to inject some action to make it more lively. I didn’t think it was necessary and there wasn’t any need for that. What I would prefer is more intrigue and inner plotting amongst the Cardinals. (There was but there was no need to the action sequence which wasn’t even a feature it happened “off screen”.)

Another thing which didn’t sit too well was it was one thing after another with the surprises. First it was this guy. Then the other. Oh, can’t forget this guy either. We already elected the pope? No wait here’s another monkey wrench. It was just too much (by the end I was screaming out: “Just give him the papacy and let’s go home. This is getting ridiculous”.) Some parts were spaced out but it just felt too much. However, good on the author to make sure all the loose ends were tied together. Nothing was left unanswered.

I liked this book but it would have been better without all the extra bits and pieces here. More intrigue and plotting within. It’s what makes it so much better. Otherwise, it was a short quick read and worth it. Just remember this is an alternate history of events.

title: Disappointing
text:
Even though I did not care for the last Julie James title, I was still looking forward to this one. Unfortunately, Love Irresistibly suffers from a few of the same issues About That Night had.

To begin with, there is very little in the way of conflicts or obstacles for the hero and heroine to overcome. The description of the book says, "A former football star and one of Chicago's top prosecutors, Assistant U.S. Attorney Cade Morgan will do anything to nail a corrupt state senator, which means he needs Brooke Parker's help. As general counsel for a restaurant company, she can get a bug to the senator's table at one of her five-star restaurants so the FBI can eavesdrop on him. All Cade has to do is convince Brooke to cooperate--and he's not afraid to use a little charm, or the power of his office, to do just that."

This isn't the storyline of the book - it's simply the way the two main characters meet. The bugging of the table and its outcome are actually over quite early in the story. From that point on, we're reading a lot about two work driven people who grant each other booty call status. Since the situation regarding the bugging of the table, and the subsequent favor Brooke calls in later are over and done with quickly and don't amount to any real meaningful part of the story, it really doesn't matter where these people work - they could have worked at Dunkin Donuts. There was very little connection in the story between the action and the type of jobs the characters have. Labeling this book part of a FBI/US Attorney series seemed rather pointless.

The rest of the story has the main characters struggling with their personal trust issues. There was a great deal of inner contemplation and discussions with friends about whether the two main characters should give in to their feelings and allow themselves to love. Honestly, all that whining and emoting began to make them sound like people on a reality show (I detest reality shows). When a frank two minute conversation between the main characters can clear up the perceived problems, there simply isn't a lot going on. I don't want to read about people thinking. I want the characters to be DOING something. Julie James' earlier titles (Practice Makes Perfect, Something About You and Just the Sexiest Man Alive) had their flaws, but they were funny and witty and the main character's occupations were actually meaningful to the story.

A few final issues...the character Zach does not sound/read like a sixteen year old boy. The voice just sounded wrong. Zach simply should have introduced himself as "Convenient Plot Progression Garrity". The constant references to hip and trendy eateries start to grate on the nerves (although I'll give you the dessert cart references - those were funny). The emphasis and descriptions of the shoes are getting tiresome and if the main female character's best friend calls her "Babe" (in any of James' novels) one more time, I may have to punch someone in the throat. The ending was abrupt. I actually turned the page to see what would happen next, only to discover that was the end of the story. And finally (I promise), is there any chance of the characters having names that aren't straight off the "Trendy Androgynous Name List"? Payton,Cameron,Rylann,Jordan,Taylor....at least Brooke was a step in the right direction, but then we went off the rails a little with the guy's names - Cade, Ford, Vaughn... All of these things add up to a lot of flash, taking away from what used to be substance.

title: Creepy!
text:
Our Crooked Hearts is the story of 17 year old Ivy, who kicks off her summer break by one night stumbling upon a strange, naked woman in the woods. What Ivy doesn’t know is that this mysterious meeting is not only the beginning of her new life, but also the culmination of a story that has been going on for decades. To understand her past and future, Ivy must face dark secrets that have been haunting her family for years.

This book has everything I love: queer witches, female friendship, difficult mother/daughter relationships, and cute romance, all wrapped in a truly creepy vibe. I loved the dual timelines: Ivy’s was the one that had me turning on every lamp in my apartment, and her mother’s had me up reading until I couldn’t keep my eyes open anymore. It’s a true page-turner of a book and even though some twists were pretty easy to guess, the ending and the entire reading experience were beyond satisfying. Ivy and her mother, Dana, are both realistic, flawed characters, and I loved watching the way their relationship changed and evolved. Reading this book felt like sitting by a campfire and listening to someone tell a scary story with unsettling forest noises as background sounds.

TLDR: Our Crooked Hearts is the perfect book for anyone who loves creep stories that are complex, well written, and simply fun to read.

title: Burning potential
text: This game revolves around conflict resolution and is player driven. Now I know your thinking, but all roleplaying games are player driven. Yes, that is true but in this system the storyteller/game master is effectively a referee and the players control the narrative, think of this game system as a way for a group of storytellers to all run a game revolving around their character while simultaneously creating content for the other players in the game to use and be a part of.  If you’re a novice to Table top then this isn’t the system for you, if you’re used to playing DND and have never had the urge to run your own game then this isn’t the system for you. If you are a seasoned roleplayer who revels in bouncing ideas back and forth while getting in-depth with the world then this is the game for you.

title: Popper misunderstands Parmenides completely
text:
Sir Karl Popper writes: "Parmenides opened my eyes to the poetic beauty of the Earth and the starry heavens, and he taught me to consider them with a new searching look. He adds: It (Parmenides’ approach to understand the world) was, for all I know, the first deductive theory of the world, the first deductive cosmology: One further step led to theoretical physics, ... "

What Popper writes about Parmenides and other Pre-Socratics is wishful thinking, far from representing these wise sages who knew the path to get in contact with the reality based on: “We are in contact with true reality, if we forget all theory”. Popper gives no hint, how this ‘extraordinary reality behind the familiar one’ is to be perceived. It is the world that Parmenides calls BEING (eón). He taught the path to experience it.

Poppers misinterpretation of Parmenides results from misconceiving BEING (eón), commonly thought to be Being (familiar world), and Non-BEING (mè eón), commonly thought to be Nonbeing (opposite of Being). This is wrong. Popper has to be excused. Already Parmenides criticized his contemporaries who mixed up BEING with Non-BEING:

1. … they (people) are carried along deaf and blind alike, dazed, beasts without judgement, convinced that „to be (BEING)“ and „not to be (Non-BEING)“ are the same and not the same (B 6.5-9).

The correct interpretation is: Non-BEING is Being, the created world of the familiar senses, and BEING is the eternally creative world that creates it by emanation. This is the original interpretation, which got lost with the disappearance of the unwritten philosophía with the closure of the last neo-Platonic schools. It is required to understand the two paths of gaining two kinds of knowledge that Parmenides refers to in his poem On Nature.

The first path is the Path (hódos) to Truth (alétheia), which he also calls the path from Non-BEING (mè eón) to BEING (eón). It is based on the first cognition principle, which Parmenides taught, like all other masters of the philosophía, to his students: The consciousness and five senses can be expanded by a unique rigorous meditative self-observation that Plato calls in Phaidros (81a) the pleasurable (phaidros) practice of dying (meléte thanátou). It is the source of all knowledge (gnósis) that the philosophía provides (see my other reviews).

The second path is the path of opinion (dóxa) confined to the familiar senses. It satisfies the second cognition principle: “Being determines consciousness (German: Das Sein bestimmt das Bewusstsein)”. The familiar sciences (e.g. the natural ones) are dedicated to investigate Being. This corresponds to the path of opinion, because the investigation is based on improvable hypotheses (assumptions, conditions, conjectures like the mathematical axioms) and conclusions that must be believed in. We associate this approach with "rational thinking".

This implies that Being cannot – contrary to what most of us believe who accept that it to be the one and only or true reality – be proven to exist. The prevailing opinion is even today that its existence is obvious. But this means little. As Being is the world that has to be believed in, it means that its existence cannot be proven. Parmenides formulates this fundamental observation (B 7.1):

2. For never shall this prevail that ‘things that are not (Being = Non-BEING = mè eón)’ are (exist).

BEING, on the other hand and in juxtaposition to Being, can – believe it or not - be truly experienced and thus proven with the practice of dying by unconditioned extrasensory self-observation. I am experienced with such a practice in my Tai Chi-school that offers the Tao-path. I view it as the Chinese counterpart of the Path to Truth.

It increasingly accesses the truth (aletheía) by unconditioned recollection (anamnésis) that emerges out of itself. It cannot be questioned by the practitioner who increasingly experiences BEING with it in function of his capability to rigorously get into a quiet state of mind. Parmenides characterises BEING:

3. BEING (eón) is uncreated and indestructible, very unique, without siblings (non-dual), steadfast, not to be completed (Frag. 8).

He also calls it the ONE (hén) and recommends:

4. It is necessary to speak and to think ‘what is’; for ‘BEING (‘what truly is’) is (exists), but ‘nothing (Non-BEING = Being)’ is not (B 6.1-2).

I extract from this last quote, which is commonly mistranslated by the trivial statement “Being is and Nonbeing is not”: Practitioners (adepts of the practice of dying) should dedicate themselves not to any abstractions (i.e. conjectures by which Being is conceived). If they would, they could not perceive BEING.

I complete my criticism of Sir Karl Popper by stating that all other profound statement of Parmenides on BEING and Non-BEING can be brought in perfect agreement with what I indicate above.

Who wants to know more about the Path to Truth (Tao path) or first cognition principle taught by the “genuine Parmenides” and thus overcome the illusion (blah blah) reported about him, will find more information in The Plato Code. For a review of it see: Man, the Measure of All Things? in The Philosopher, Volume 102 No. 2, 2014.

See also my critical reviews of:

Plato: Timaeus and Critias (Penguin Classics), translated by Desmond Lee Plato Republic (Hackett Classics), translated by C. D. C. Reeve,
Plato: Symposium (Hackett Classics), translated by Alexander Nehamas and Paul Woodruff,
Plato: Republic (Hackett Classics), translated by C. D. C. Reeve,
Theology of Arithmetic, by Robin Butterfield,
The Essence of Truth: On Plato's Cave Allegory and Theaetetus (Bloomsbury Revelations), by Martin Heidegger.

For futher details see my Youtube presentation. TAO: PATH TO DISCOVER THE PSYCHO-COSMIC ORIGIN OF THE WESTERN CULTURE.

title: A Terrible Disaster with Horrible Consequences - All Extremely Well-Recounted
text:
This is a truly gripping tale. Surely most people in the world have heard of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster of April 1986. Since then, many accounts as to what “exactly” happened, etc., have surfaced – some more accurate than others and some completely misleading if not outright false. In this spellbinding book, the author sets the record straight in minute detail – before the accident, during, after and the lingering aftermath.

I found this book hard to put down. The author’s prose is clear, well-researched, lively and immensely captivating. It contains many passages that can make a reader infuriated while other passages, very sad. The suffering endured by the exposed first responders as well as exposed plant workers is pain-stakingly and heart-wrenchingly described. This book should be of interest to anyone interested in true disaster stories as well as those wondering about how not to officially react to nuclear disasters within your borders. Those fascinated by the Soviet mentality still prevalent during the period in which the accident occurred will also find much of interest here. A very well-written and engrossing read!

text: I enjoy both of my daily ukes, but find I go to book one more. I'm not one for collections as I don't like lugging around a heavy book that I personally only want to play about 25% of.. but, it's good for clubs and I have rediscovered some music that I probably wouldn't have found my way back to, if it weren't for these books. I would have liked the digital version for my ipad but I previewed book 1 sample and found that you could not increase the size of the actual sheet music, increasing the font size only changed the title and extraneous text. The size of the lyrics and Chords were just way too small for me to read comfortably. Too bad, especially since my uke group uses both 1 and 2 and they are alot to lug.  The book is laid out nicely, and plastic spiral lays good and flat for playing and has help up well despite heavy use. Chord diagrams at top of each song is nice, especially for some of the older songs that have many chord changes and use less well known chords. Good go-to books for a uke group with mixed ages, something for most everyone (but leans toward being better for older folks).

title: Tries to do too much
text:
So tell me if you're familiar with these elements: evil Nazis victorious (check), alternative world (check), traveling between said words (check), exotic weaponry (check), occult nonsense (check). Most science fiction readers get an easy 5 out 5. The trouble here is that the novel tries to do it all and it devolves into a "turn the page" mess.

If Man in the High Castle and Indiana Jones had a lovechild this is what you'd get. It was simultaneously historical, funny, confusing and of course we get the action scenes thrown in for good measure. ****** Plot Reveal ******* The idea that Germany could "fool" the entire world and develop an atomic bomb (20 kt at that) years before the Americans sounded fancifull - and it was. No, they took the easy way out - zero point energy (LOL) And naturally it's all related to occult nonsense that I chose not to follow because it made less than zero sense.

Oddly, the idea of such a "victory" could have been the basis for a great novel is the author had been so inclined. But this would have meant discarding the other-worldly plot devices that were central to the story. My Grade - C

title: The relationships between sisters can run the gamut of best friends for life to wanting to choke the life ...
text:
The relationships between sisters can run the gamut of best friends for life to wanting to choke the life of out each other. With Dara and Nick, it runs somewhere in between. They are only eleven months apart with Nick being the elder. Nick also wears the title of perfect older sister to Dara's rebellious little sister. They each feel they have very defined roles in their family. There are a lot of underlying issues both sisters have with each other not the least of which is resentment. Nick resents Dara for having to clean up the messes her rebellions make and Dara resents Nick for always being first and best.

The sisters' relationship is not the only one explored but it is kept central to the story. The secondary relationships allow the reader to see how Dara and Nick relate to the people in their lives. So much of the push of the story hinges on the finding the truth of what happened on the night of the accident. Through experiencing memories of before the accident, we see how Dara and Nick's relationship had begun to deteriorate with neither one of them knowing how to fix the ever growing rift between them. I loved how even while you feel the animosity between them, there is still the underlying love they will always have for each other.

The plot twist took me by surprise and being surprised took me by surprised. (You know what I mean.) I usually, but not always, figure out what the twist is, or have some clue before the big reveal but not this time. This time when I read the plot twist my reaction ran along the lines of "wait...what?" I had to re-read the section in order to absorb what had happened. A shrink might say I didn't see it coming because I didn't want it to be true. Whatever the reason, I didn't like it and I'll leave it at that.

Even after my reaction to the plot twist, I still enjoyed the overall story. Oliver can write, there's no denying it. She is able to make her characters feel an array of strong emotions all while conveying those emotions to the reader, making this story a page turner.

Rating: A-

title: The duality of the southern thing
text:
I enjoyed this book. I probably wasn't as invested as some people got to be in my love of Scout or of Atticus, so perhaps I didn't have as much to get over as some others had to while reading this book.
This book can easily be read as a stand alone book.
There has been a lot of talk and concern about which book was written first and/or when etc. Regardless of these questions, this book is well timed. It is relevant right now for many of the same reasons that To Kill a Mockingbird was important for its time.
It is very well written and was a joy to read. I found it to be essentially realistic; with some of "the duality of the southern thing", as the Drive By Truckers intoned in the song, The Three Alabama Icons.
This book is about growing up and about how grown up we think we are, even in old age, and how far we have to go. And this holds true for a community/society just as it does for the individual. Most of all this book is is about how difficult it can be to love and how right it is to care throughout the difficult process of loving or learning to love.
This is a coming of age book; a mature book intent upon more maturity in, or at, any age. When it comes to state's rights, if we're not still fighting the civil war, we still seem far from reconstruction. But I think we are slowly growing up.

title: A powerful and moving story
text:
Catherine Mann's Honorable Intentions takes the reader on an emotional journey.

Major Hank Renshaw, Jr. returns to New Orleans to deliver a message to his best friend's fiancée. Kevin died on the battle field in Hank's arms and his dying message was for his fiancée Gabrielle Ballard. Kevin's death was painful in itself but Hank yearned for Gabrielle in secret as well.

Gabrielle Ballard is trying to hold it all together. She is trying to go to school and take care of her sickly infant son. Gabrielle is shocked to see Hank Renshaw on her doorstep. He says he is there to help her anyway he can but Gabrielle is used to depending on only herself. She takes Hank up on his offer of a place to stay when her apartment is flooded. Gabrielle is grateful for the sanctuary when her son is also scheduled for lifesaving surgery.

Hank and Gabrielle have always ignored the feelings they have for each other but spending so much time together they finally give into their desires. Will Hank be able to convince Gabrielle that he is with her for more then just duty?

Honorable Intentions is a gem. The story of battle and a sickly child will tug at your heart. Hank Renshaw's story has been long awaited and well worth the wait. Hank and Gabrielle's story is a very moving and sensual story. Catherine Mann delivers another stellar story.
